entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French pygoun, pijun, from Late Latin pipion-, pipio young bird, from Latin pipire to chirp

def.dt: :any of a widely distributed family (Columbidae, order Columbiformes) of birds with a stout body, rather short legs, and smooth and compact plumage
:a member of any of numerous varieties of the rock dove that exist in domestication and in the feral state in cities and towns throughout most of the world
:an object of special concern :accepted business or interest tennis was not his pigeon
:a deformity of the chest marked by sharp projection of the sternum
:merlin used for one of No. America
:a leguminous shrubby herb (Cajanus cajan) with trifoliate leaves, yellow flowers, and flattened pods that is much cultivated especially in the tropics
:having the toes and forefoot turned inward
:any of a breed of large long-bodied show pigeons
:a saucer-shaped target usually made of baked clay or limestone and pitch and thrown from a trap in skeet and trapshooting
:a racing pigeon trained to return home
